H0.text: Increased digestion rate is the adaptation necessary for a predator that becomes tired more quickly after being moved from sea level to a higher altitude, allowing it to survive at the higher altitude.

H1.text: Growth of additional teeth is the adaptation necessary for the predator to survive at higher altitude, because biologists observed it became tired more quickly when the predator was moved from sea level.

H2.text: Reduction of respiration rate would be necessary for a predator that becomes tired more quickly when moved from sea level to a higher altitude, allowing it to survive there.

H3.text: Production of more red blood cells would be necessary for the predator to survive at higher altitude, where it becomes tired more quickly after being moved from sea level.

A4.text: Other physiological changes that occur in rodents at high altitude include increased breathing rate

A5.text: The body's response to high altitude includes the production of additional red blood cells.

A6.text: The body's response to high altitude includes increased minute ventilation (hence both low CO2, and subsequently bicarbonate).
